source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: The reactivity of the zirconium alloy with O2 at room temperature is about 1000 times higher than for H2O

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: The reactivity of the zirconium alloy with O2 at room temperature is about 1000 times higher than for H2O

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Up to 100 L (1 L = 1 Langmuir unit = 1·10^{-6} mbar·s) H2O exposure, the reactivity of the zirconium alloy at 450°C is comparable to the room temperature reaction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: At higher H2O exposure, a sharp increase in the reaction rate for the high-temperature oxidation is observed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: After an oxide thickness of 2 nm, the stoichiometric ZrO2 phase is not yet developed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: After an oxide thickness of 2 nm, the stoichiometric ZrO2 phase is not yet developed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: samples were cut from Zircaloy sheet materials containing $1 . 3 \%$ tin, $0 . 2 \%$ iron, $0 . 1 \%$ chromium and $0 , 1 3 \%$ oxygen

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: mechanically polished using a 0.5- $\mu \mathrm { m }$ fine grain diamond polish in the final step

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Initial precleaning of samples before in situ oxidation was done by ${ \mathfrak { s } } – \mathbf { k } e \mathbf { V }$ argon ion bombardment under normal or grazing incidence at room temperature or at $4 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: ex situ oxidized material was prepared in a static stainless steel autoclave under steam at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ and $1 0 5 \mathrm { M P a }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: in situ oxidation was performed in the ultra-high vacuum system introducing oxygen or water by opening a leak valve to an amount that established a constant pressure of $1 \cdot 1 0 ^ { - 6 }$ mbar in the system

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The mounted samples were held under ultrahigh vacuum conditions $( < 2 ~ \cdot ~ 1 0 ^ { - 1 0 }$ mbar) during the measurements and during the heattreatment experiments

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The sample-to-analyzer geometry and the photon energy was kept fixed at a constant information depth of $0 . 6 \ \mathrm { n m }$ for the emitted photoelectrons

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The two registration techniques have different information depths of about ${ 2 0 \ \mathrm { n m } }$ (using electron yield) and $5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (fluorescence), respectively

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: there was a trace of oxygen remaining detectable. It corresponds to an amount of less than 0.1 monolayer of zirconium oxide

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: iron and oxygen were clearly seen, but similar to the XPS investigation, no chromium or tin signal was detected

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Heating of the clean zirconium alloy for $6 0 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ to $4 5 0 \%$ in ultra-high vacuum (UHV) results in the visual appearance of small shiny spots about $0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ in diameter on the surface

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Absorption measurements on these spots show an iron enrichment

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: In the shiny spot on the sample, no chromium is detected

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: X-ray absorption spectrum that shows the locally segregated iron enrichment spots after heat treatment at 450°C due to the increase of the Fe 2p absorption edge

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: Two samples of the same alloy have been oxidized ex-situ in a stainless steel autoclave under steam at 400°C, 105 MPa

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The thickness of the pretransition oxide obtained after three-day autoclave treatment was 0.5 μm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The post-transition oxide formed after 30 days exhibited a 3.5-μm thickness as determined by infrared spectroscopy (FTIR)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: in-situ oxide, prepared at 450°C, has not reached the full ZrO₂ structure

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: Heating of the native oxide results in the disappearance of nearly 70% of the oxide film

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: Oxides grown under autoclave oxidation showed a considerable amount of iron and chromium at the surface

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: On the clean Zircaloy surface, chromium and iron were below the detection limit

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The samples precleaned under UHV were exposed to water, and the oxidation reaction was followed by XPS

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The exposure range was from 1 L H₂O (1 L = 1 Langmuir = 1.10⁻⁶ mbar·s) to 1·10⁵ L H₂O

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The spin-orbit splitting of 2.37 eV was determined by the evaluation of the spectra from clean Zircaloy and of the native zirconium oxide

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk3
evidence_span: The difference of the two values was less than 0.03 eV

evidence_span: Suboxide (1) was reported to be at $- 1 . 2 \mathfrak { e } \mathbf { V }$ and Suboxide () at $- 3 . 3 \ \mathsf { e V }$

evidence_span: Suboxide (1) was reported to be at $- 1 . 2 \mathfrak { e } \mathbf { V }$ and Suboxide () at $- 3 . 3 \ \mathsf { e V }$

evidence_span: The in situ reaction of the zirconium with ${ \bf H } _ { 2 } { \bf O }$ at $4 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ is shown in Fig. 7

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk4
evidence_span: at the $1 0 0 \mathbf { L } \mathbf { H } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O }$ exposure, a monolayer of oxide is developed

evidence_span: A comparison between room temperature and $4 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ kinetics of Suboxide (2) formation is presented in Fig. 9. The sharp increase for high temperature reaction can be clearly seen

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: significant differences in the reactivity between water and oxygen to Zircaloy can be concluded

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Even at this high exposure (5 mbar · min), the bulk metal peak did not totally vanish in contrast to the situation for the oxygen oxidation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: after 5 mbar · min O2 exposure, the substrate signal vanished completely

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: A detailed comparison of the spectra showed similar intensities in the spectrum for an oxide formed by 111 L O2 to one of 1·10^5 L H2O. This is a factor of ~1000 in the exposure time and therefore reactivity.
property_name: exposure ratio for equivalent oxide formation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: significant differences in the tendency exists between water and oxygen to form an oxide layer at the Zircaloy surface

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: the higher reactivity of oxygen favors the formation of O adsorption layers

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Photo emission spectra as a function of H2O exposure at 450°C showing the shift of the Zr 3d doublet with oxide formation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Detailed analysis of the spectra of the high temperature water adsorption experiment (Fig. 7) using least square fit procedures. Energy shifts are measured against the metal bulk line.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Comparison of reactivity for the oxidation of Zircaloy by water at room temperature and 450°C.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Comparison of the room temperature H2O and O2 reaction with the zirconium alloy. The spectrum of 1·10^5 L H2O compares well to the spectrum of 111 L O2. For the same coverage, a factor of nearly 1000 higher H2O exposure is needed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: The mean free path of the photoelectrons, λ, at kinetic energies ~120 eV is 0.6 nm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: At our detection geometry, θ equals 90° and is kept constant.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the oxide thickness of the zirconium alloy that reacted with water at room temperature

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the oxide thickness of the zirconium alloy that reacted with water at $4 5 0 \mathrm { ^ \circ C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: The base oxide thickness from where the rapid increase starts is 0.3 to $\mathbf { 0 . 4 n m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: For $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } \mathbf { O } _ { 2 }$ , $\mathbf { \delta } d _ { 0 }$ equals $\mathbf { 0 . 3 3 \ n m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: The highest oxide thickness of $2 . 4 \ \mathrm { n m }$ at $1 0 0 0 0 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the thickness of the native oxide can be calculated to be at least $7 \mathrm { \mathfrak { n m } }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the low reactivity of the Zircaloy at $4 5 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ in the initial exposure region is surprising

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: At room temperature, a more continuous increase to thicker oxide is observed

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the mean free path, $\pmb { \lambda }$ , of $1 . 8 \ \mathrm { n m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: the extension where then the Suboxide (2) structures are converted to stoichiometric $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } \mathbf { O } _ { 2 }$ is more than $2 \mathsf { n m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The energy position of the chemically-shifted Zr 3d line moves toward the value of the stable ZrO2, but does not reach it within the first 2 nm during water reaction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: An 100 L O2 exposure results in the same coverage as 100000 L H2O.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The thickness of the oxide layer after reaction with water at 450°C is initially low, but sharply increases as a function of the exposure.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4, in three different metallurgical forms (stress relieved, recrystallized, and β-quenched), was oxidized at 400°C in steam, up to 95 days.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: For each sample, the fraction of tetragonal zirconia was measured by x-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: These two techniques show the presence of several zones containing tetragonal zirconia: a zone rich in the oxide near the metal-oxide interface and an other zones with lower concentrations in the rest of the pre-transition layers.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: For the post-transition samples, the external sublayer contains only a small amount of tetragonal zirconia.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: Measurements of residual stresses by x-ray diffraction in the metal underlying the oxide show that the metal is under tensile stress state and that the stress values vary with oxidation duration.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The level of the stress depends on the metallurgical form of the initial metal.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The low penetration of x-rays in the material also made it possible to show the presence of a very high stress gradient near the metal-oxide interface that can explain the high proportion of tetragonal zirconia near the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The study of the incorporation of intermetallic precipitates in the oxide and their chemical changes was carried out by electron microprobe analysis on taper cross sections of the oxide.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The intermetallic precipitates are incorporated into the oxide layer and then undergo a chemical change starting at a particular distance from the metal/oxide interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The characteristic values of the Fe/Cr ratio before oxidation (1.6 for stress relieved and recrystallized conditions and 0.8 for β-quenched samples) are progressively spread out during oxidation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The characteristic values of the Fe/Cr ratio before oxidation (1.6 for stress relieved and recrystallized conditions and 0.8 for β-quenched samples) are progressively spread out during oxidation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: The oxidation of the precipitates is accompanied by a volume change that should lead to the formation of a stress field around the precipitates and could stabilize the neighboring tetragonal phase.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: When the precipitates are completely oxidized, the stress field disappears and there is a transformation of the tetragonal phase to a monoclinic form, leading to the kinetic transition.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: Stress relaxation is shown by a decrease of the tensile stresses in the metal underlying the oxide that is undergoing kinetic transition.
